In 2023, in North-America, what are employers looking for in a Curriculum Vitae. What are some best practices to create a resume that will make me look employable?

Employers in North America in 2023 are looking for a concise and easy-to-read Curriculum Vitae (CV) that highlights relevant work experience and education that align with the job requirements. When building a resume, it's important to keep in mind that employers only spend about 10-15 seconds reviewing each resume, so it's crucial to have all relevant information on the first page. Some best practices include using clear and concise language, tailoring your resume to the job you're applying for, highlighting your relevant skills and accomplishments, and making sure your resume is free of typos or formatting errors.

In 2023, employers in North America will be looking for resumes that clearly demonstrate the candidate's qualifications and experience. They want to see a clear career path and accomplishments that are relevant to the job they are applying for. 

Some best practices for creating an effective resume include: 
• Keeping it concise - avoid long paragraphs or lists of responsibilities; instead focus on achievements and results. 
• Tailoring your resume to each job you apply for - highlight skills, experiences, and education related to the position you’re applying for. 
• Highlighting key words from the job description - use these words throughout your resume so it is easier for employers to find what they need quickly. 
• Proofreading your work - make sure there are no typos or grammar errors as this could reflect poorly on you as a potential employee. 
• Including contact information at the top of the page - make sure your name, phone number, email address, and other contact information is easy to find at the top of your CV/resume.

When applying for a job and making a CV:

• Be truthful and relevant. Quirky CV have a much lower acceptance rate than plain and direct ones. Lying in a CV just loses everybody's time and gives you useless experience.
• Be readable. Ensure the layout of your CV is clear and consistent, containing only 1 font type (**bold** can be used to highlight) and using bullet points to outline skills.
• Be specific. Tailor your CV to each particular job that you apply for. If you don’t document your skills and experience clearly in your CV; you may fall at the first hurdle.
• Be consistent. Give a clear, reverse chronological order with no unexplained time lapses (irrelevant jobs may be left to a single specification).
• Be knowledgeable. Know in advance what is important in the job you seek. Specify all relevant skills gained and required of you for this job in your previous roles.
• Be valid. If you have had years of experience in the wrong branch of the job you seek (or in a different job), explain why your experience is still valid.
• Be effective. Hiring managers love to see results. Give a clear way to understand where you added value, and your exact contribution to any high profile project.
• Be efficient. Use relevant language. The person reading it may not be a technical or industry expert, however they will know what to look out for.
• Be certified. Ensure you highlight relevant educational certificates.
• Be identifiable. No hiring manager wants to download software to view a CV. Include your name i.e. Smith-John-CV in the file title.

• Be original. All of the above should ***paint you as yourself***, which is exactly what "being original" means. You are unlikely to have the same experiences as anybody else. However, as a rule of thumb: avoid including anything generic like "I have excellent communication skills" or "a great team player" all of which are just a waste of space, time, and you.

To install the exact version of a package, in your requirements.txt, specify the version

requirements.txt
```
package_name==2.0.3
```

To install a version > 2.03
```
package_name==2.0.3
```

The comparison operator determines the kind of version clause:
~=: Compatible release clause
==: Version matching clause
!=: Version exclusion clause
<=, >=: Inclusive ordered comparison clause
<, >: Exclusive ordered comparison clause
===: Arbitrary equality clause.
The comma (",") is equivalent to a logical and operator: a candidate version must match all given version clauses in order to match the specifier as a whole.

You can specify exact versions of packages in your requirements.txt file by using the == operator. For example, if you wanted to install version 2.0.3 of a package, you would write the following in your requirements.txt file:

package_name==2.0.3

If you wanted to install a version that is at least 2.0.3, you would use the >= operator. For example:

package_name>=2.0.3

Inside of your requirements.txt file, you can use special syntax to define the version requirements for each of the packages. In your case, you could use the following line in your requirements.txt to require a package with a version of 2.0.3 or higher:
```
my_package=>2.0.3
```

The requirements.txt file contains the versions of the packages that will be installed. To ensure that pip installs the correct versions of the packages, you should check that the versions listed in the requirements.txt file are the ones you want. You can also specify the version you want to be installed when running the command, like so: pip install <package-name>==<version>.

The requirements.txt file contains not only a list of packages but also a version number for each package. The pip install will only install the specified version of those packages, if it can't the process will fail.

Tell me more about World economic forum

The World Economic Forum (WEF) is an international non-governmental and lobbying organisation based in Cologny, canton of Geneva, Switzerland. It was founded on 24 January 1971 by German engineer and economist Klaus Schwab. The foundation, which is mostly funded by its 1,000 member companies – typically global enterprises with more than US$5 billion in turnover – as well as public subsidies, views its own mission as "improving the state of the world by engaging business, political, academic, and other leaders of society to shape global, regional, and industry agendas"

The World Economic Forum (WEF) is an international organization that aims to improve the state of the world by engaging business, political, academic, and other leaders of society to shape global, regional, and industry agendas. It was founded in 1971 as a not-for-profit foundation and is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland.

The WEF organizes an annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland, bringing together leaders from various sectors and countries to discuss and address the world's most pressing issues, such as the global economy, poverty, inequality, and environmental challenges. The meeting provides a platform for leaders to network, exchange ideas, and collaborate on solutions.

The WEF also conducts research, provides education and training programs, and creates initiatives and partnerships to tackle global issues. Through its various activities, the WEF aims to be a catalyst for positive change and to help shape a more inclusive, sustainable, and prosperous future for all.
Where would you find a nice meal in New York?

With a budget of $80 for two people, there are many great options for dining in New York. Here are a few recommendations:

1. Joe's Pizza: This is a classic New York-style pizza joint that has been around since 1975. It is known for its thin, crispy crust and delicious toppings, and you can get a whole pie for around $20.

2. Xi'an Famous Foods: This is a fast-casual restaurant that specializes in Chinese street food, particularly the cuisine of the Shaanxi region. They offer a variety of dishes, including hand-pulled noodles and spicy lamb burgers, that are both delicious and affordable (most dishes are under $10).

3. Los Tacos No. 1: If you're in the mood for Mexican food, this is a great spot for authentic tacos made with fresh, homemade tortillas. Most tacos are around $4 each, so you can easily fill up for under $20.

4. The Halal Guys: This food cart turned restaurant is famous for its delicious halal food, including gyros, falafel, and chicken over rice. A platter typically costs around $10, and it's enough to feed two people.

5. Vanessa's Dumpling House: This is a popular spot for Chinese dumplings, buns, and other snacks. You can get a generous serving of dumplings for around $5, making it a great budget-friendly option.

All of these restaurants are affordable, delicious, and located in different neighborhoods throughout New York City, so you can choose the one that best suits your tastes and itinerary.

From dives to fine dining establishments, New York City is home to numerous fantastic eateries. Katz's Delicatessen on the Lower East Side is a top pick for real deli cuisine, and Sylvia's in Harlem is a top choice for soul food. Some well-liked locations include Smorgasburg, where you can sample a variety of unusual and delicious delicacies, and The Hugh, a chic new food hall in Midtown East.

If you are referring to a polynomial expression in mathematics, then a polynomial is an expression consisting of variables and coefficients, that involves only the operations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and positive-integer powers of variables. The word polynomial was derived from the term binomial by replacing the Latin root "bi" with "poly" meaning many in Greek.

Do you have anything else you would like to know regarding polynomials?
Could you explain with the math formula?

Sure. Some examples of polynomials may give some clarity
2x^2 + 5x - 7
6x - 1
11x^3 - x
5x^4 + 9x^3 - 2x^2 + 8x + 3

In these examples, x is the variable, the coefficients are the numbers that appear right before x, and the "powers" are the numbers that appear right after ^

Take for example: 2x^2 + 5x - 7
2 is the coefficient of x^2, 5 is the coefficient of x, -7 is called the "constant" term.
We would speak out this polynomial as "two x to the power of two plus five x minus 7"
People will often say "squared" instead of "to the power of two", and "cubed" instead of "to the power of three".

Let's look at one more of the examples: 5x^4 + 9x^3 - 2x^2 + 8x + 3
Spoken aloud this polynomial would be "five x to the power of four plus nine x cubed minus two x squared plus eight x plus 3"
The coefficient of x^4 is 5, the coefficient of x^3 is 9, the coefficient of x^2 is -2, the coefficient of x is 8, and the constant term is 3.

a_n*x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + ... + a_1x + a_0

Here, x is a variable, a_n to a_0 are constants known as coefficients, and n is a non-negative integer representing the degree of the polynomial. The degree of a polynomial is determined by the highest power of x that appears in the expression.

For example, the polynomial 2x^3 + 3x^2 - 5x + 7 is a third-degree polynomial since the highest power of x is 3.

Advocating for more apartments in your city is an important political issue, and organizing a local political movement can be a powerful way to make your voice heard. Here is an action plan to help you get started:

1. Identify supporters: Start by identifying people who share your concerns about the need for more apartments in your city. This can include friends, family, coworkers, and neighbors. You can also reach out to community organizations and social media groups to find people who are interested in your cause.

2. Research the issue: Educate yourself about the local housing market and the policies that affect it. Find out how many apartments are currently available in your city, how much they cost, and how they are distributed across different neighborhoods. Look into zoning regulations, building codes, and other laws that affect the development of new apartments.

3. Develop a message: Craft a clear and compelling message that explains why more apartments are needed in your city. Emphasize the benefits of increased housing supply, such as lower rents, more diverse neighborhoods, and reduced traffic congestion. Make sure your message is easy to understand and resonates with your target audience.

4. Build a coalition: Reach out to other organizations and individuals who share your goals. This could include local business groups, advocacy organizations, and housing developers. Work together to develop a common agenda and build a broader base of support for your cause.

5. Develop a plan of action: Decide on specific actions you can take to advance your cause. This could include organizing rallies or protests, holding meetings with local officials, writing letters to the editor or op-eds, or launching a social media campaign. Make sure you have a clear plan in place and assign responsibilities to different members of your team.

6. Reach out to local officials: Meet with local officials and make your case for why more apartments are needed in your city. This could include city council members, planning board members, and other decision-makers. Be prepared to explain your position and provide data and evidence to support your arguments.

7. Mobilize your supporters: Get your supporters involved in your advocacy efforts. Encourage them to attend rallies and meetings, write letters to officials, and share your message on social media. The more people you can mobilize, the more impact you will have.

8. Monitor progress: Keep track of your progress and adjust your strategy as needed. Track how many apartments are being built, how much they cost, and where they are located. Monitor changes in zoning regulations and other policies that affect housing development. Use this information to adjust your message and tactics to ensure that you are making the most effective use of your resources.

By following these steps, you can organize a local political movement that advocates for more apartments in your city. With dedication and persistence, you can make a real difference in your community and help improve the lives of many people.

What is the purpose of common table expressions in SQL and when should you use them?
Could you include small examples?

A Common Table Expression (CTE) is a temporary result set derived from a SELECT statement, and can be used in a SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement. CTEs are used to simplify complex queries by breaking them down into smaller, more manageable pieces.

The purpose of CTEs is to make queries easier to read, write and maintain. CTEs can be thought of as named subqueries or temporary views that are only visible within the scope of a single SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement. They are not stored as objects in the database and do not impact database performance.

CTEs are particularly useful when dealing with complex queries that involve multiple levels of data aggregation or calculations, or when the same subquery is used in multiple places in a larger query. Using a CTE allows you to write the subquery once and reuse it throughout the query, making the overall structure of the query simpler and easier to understand.

In terms of when to use CTEs, they are a good choice when you want to:

Break down a complex query into smaller, more manageable pieces.
Improve query readability and maintainability by giving meaningful names to intermediate results.
Reuse intermediate results within the same query.
Simplify complex calculations or aggregations by breaking them down into multiple steps.
In general, if you have a query that is becoming difficult to understand or maintain due to its complexity, a CTE may be a good solution to simplify the query and make it easier to work with.
What are some basic examples?

Let’s say you have a table called schools with the columns ```school_id```, ```school_name```, ```district_id```, and the number of students.
You need to write a query to display a list of schools alongside their district ID and the average number of students per school in that district.

Your logic might be as follows:

    Create a table with the list of districts and the corresponding average number of students per school.
    Join this table with the list of schools and display the required information.
    Drop the table with the average number of students per school for each district.

If you use a CTE (Common Table Expression), you don’t need to create and drop a table. You can simply reference the temporary result set created by the "WITH" query, like you see below:

```
WITH avg_students AS (
SELECT district_id, AVG(students) as average_students
FROM schools
GROUP BY district_id)
SELECT s.school_name, s.district_id, avg.average_students
FROM schools s
JOIN avg_students avg
ON s.district_id = avg.district_id;
```

So, here you start by defining the temporary result set ```avg_students``` in the "WITH" query. In the brackets, there is a "SELECT" statement that defines this result set; it contains a list of districts and the corresponding average number of students per school. After the closing parenthesis, you start the main "SELECT" statement. Notice that you reference the temporary result set just like an ordinary table, using its assigned name (```avg_students```). The output will include the school name, the ID of its district, and the average number of students in this district. 


| school_name | district_id | average_students |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Happy Kid | 2 | 238 |
| Smart | 2 | 238 |
| Sun | 5 | 176 |
| Montessori | 5 | 176 |


In the sense that it can’t be used in any other SQL queries, the temporary result set is “dropped”. Of course, you can define it again if you need to.

Here are some basic examples of using CTEs in SQL:

Calculating the cumulative sum of a column:

WITH cumulative_sum AS (
  SELECT 
    order_id, 
    order_date, 
    order_total, 
    SUM(order_total) OVER (ORDER BY order_date) AS running_total
  FROM orders
)
SELECT 
  order_id, 
  order_date, 
  order_total, 
  running_total
FROM cumulative_sum;

Breaking down a complex query into multiple steps:

WITH customer_info AS (
  SELECT 
    customer_id, 
    customer_name, 
    city, 
    state
  FROM customers
),
order_info AS (
  SELECT 
    order_id, 
    customer_id, 
    order_date, 
    order_total
  FROM orders
)
SELECT 
  customer_info.customer_name, 
  order_info.order_date, 
  order_info.order_total
FROM customer_info
JOIN order_info 
  ON customer_info.customer_id = order_info.customer_id;

Reusing intermediate results:

WITH top_customers AS (
  SELECT 
    customer_id, 
    SUM(order_total) AS total_spend
  FROM orders
  GROUP BY customer_id
),
top_10_customers AS (
  SELECT 
    customer_id
  FROM top_customers
  ORDER BY total_spend DESC
  LIMIT 10
)
SELECT 
  customer_id, 
  order_date, 
  order_total
FROM orders
WHERE customer_id IN (SELECT customer_id FROM top_10_customers);

In these examples, the CTEs are used to simplify the overall structure of the query and make it easier to understand and maintain.

Common Table Expressions (CTEs) are a feature in SQL that allow you to define a temporary named result set that can be used within a SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement. They provide a way to simplify complex queries and improve readability by breaking down a query into smaller, reusable parts.

CTEs can be thought of as named subqueries, as they can be used to encapsulate a query and refer to it later in the same statement. The key difference between subqueries and CTEs is that subqueries are unnamed and can only be used within the same query, while CTEs can be named and can be referred to multiple times within a query.

You should use CTEs when you have a complex query that needs to be broken down into smaller, more manageable parts. They can also be used to improve the readability and maintainability of a query by giving meaningful names to intermediate results. Additionally, CTEs can provide performance benefits, as the query optimizer may be able to use the results of a CTE multiple times without having to recompute them each time.

Here's an example of a query that uses a CTE:

vbnet

WITH TotalSales AS (
   SELECT CustomerID, SUM(Amount) AS TotalAmount
   FROM Orders
   GROUP BY CustomerID
)
SELECT Customers.Name, TotalAmount
FROM Customers
JOIN TotalSales ON Customers.CustomerID = TotalSales.CustomerID

In this example, the CTE named "TotalSales" is used to compute the total sales for each customer. The results of the CTE are then used in the main query to join with the customers table and retrieve the customer name and total sales.

Create a story about a talking cat named Fluffball who teaches magic to young wizards. Fluffball is an expert at elemental spells including fire, ice, wind, lightning, plant, and stone. Fluffball does not like to be petted.

Once upon a time, in a magical kingdom far far away, there lived a talking cat named Fluffball. Fluffball was unlike any other cat, as it had the ability to cast powerful spells and control the elements. Despite its magical abilities, Fluffball was known to be a grumpy cat and did not like to be petted or touched in any way.

Fluffball lived in a wizarding academy, where young and aspiring wizards came to learn the art of magic. The academy was known for its rigorous curriculum and high standards, and Fluffball was one of the most respected teachers there.

Fluffball's specialty was elemental magic and it had mastered the spells of fire, ice, wind, lightning, plant, and stone. The young wizards were in awe of Fluffball's abilities and often sought its guidance to perfect their own spells.

One day, a young wizard named Lily approached Fluffball with a request. She wanted to learn the most powerful elemental spells and become a master wizard like Fluffball. Fluffball, who was known for its stern and strict demeanor, agreed to teach Lily and took her under its paw.

Lily was a hardworking student and practiced day and night, determined to impress Fluffball. She soon discovered that casting spells was not just about the incantations, but also about the heart and soul that went into it.

Under Fluffball's guidance, Lily grew in her powers and learned to control the elements with grace and ease. She soon became the star pupil of the academy, and her spells were the talk of the town.

However, Lily's journey was not without its challenges. One day, she was faced with a powerful and evil wizard who threatened the peace of the kingdom. Lily was scared but remembered Fluffball's words and summoned all her courage. With a fierce determination, she cast a spell and defeated the evil wizard, saving the kingdom and its people.

Fluffball, who was watching from the sidelines, was proud of Lily's achievements. For the first time, it showed a rare smile and even let Lily pet it, signifying its approval and respect for the young wizard.

From that day on, Lily and Fluffball became the best of friends, and their adventures continued as they explored the magical kingdom and its wonders. Lily was grateful to have Fluffball as her mentor, and Fluffball was grateful to have found a student who was worthy of its teachings.

The talking cat named Fluffball and the young wizard Lily were remembered for generations as two of the greatest magic-users to have ever lived in the kingdom, and their story served as an inspiration to all young wizards who aspired to be like them.

In the distant future, technology has advanced to the point that it is possible for people to upload their minds into a virtual world. A person named Roe recently underwent the mind upload process and has been exploring the virtual world and all the wonders it contains.

Roe continues to live in the virtual world for so long that they are beg to forget what the real world is like. After realizing this, Roe desires to exit the virtual world, but has been inside it for so long, they have forgotten what steps they need to take to exit the virtual world. All they remember is the first step in the exit sequence, which is to go to the virtual world's shipping port.

Roe travels to the port hoping that the sight of the port will jog their memory on the next step of the exit sequence.

Upon arriving to the port, Roe cannot remember what the next step is. In a panic, Roe interacts with other people at the port to ask if they can show them the next step. Unfortunately, everyone they talk to is too immersed in experience of the virtual world and cannot understand why they would want to leave.

Roe continues to search for someone who is willing to help them. Standing at the end of one of the docks at the port, Roe sees a young woman who is waving her hands in strange patterns in the air. Curious about her odd behavior, Roe asks the young woman what she is doing. Surprised at the question, the young lady states that she is performing her exit sequence.

Filled with hope, Roe begs the young lady to show them how to perform the exit sequence. The young lady agrees and begins waiving her hands again and says, "your exit sequence is set when you enter the virtual world and must be performed at the port." She continues, "It consists of a series of three hand gestures." After doing two hand gestures, the young lady begins to fade, becoming almost transparent. Roe, fearing she will disappear before they can learn the sequence earnestly asks were he can learn their hand gestures. The young lady makes her last gesture says, "only you know that," and vanishes from sight.

Standing on the dock alone, Roe feels their stomach drop as they realizes that they have forgotten their exit sequence and will not be able to leave until they remember it.

My dad always used to tell me about the old days, when he was a kid. He would tell me about the farm he grew up on, the animals he fed, and the innocent, joyous life he led. Despite its innocuous nature and inherent simplicity, it was, and still is my favourite story of his. A subtle tip of the hat to the man he was. I suppose though that the real reason I am drawn to his story is how impossible it seems. How distant and unattainable that peacefulness truly is.

“Huuuuuhh!” I breathed a deep, choking breath. My heart pounded like a dog on a chain, sweat dripping from my ears like there was no tomorrow. I looked up, still in a trance of adrenaline as my vision begun to straighten itself out. Panting for air, I unplugged myself and went to the kitchen to make a coffee, god I needed a coffee. Going in really takes it out of you, especially as that was my third time going in for the day.
"Hey", Michelle, my wife, said as the walked into the room. The kettle clicked off.
"Yeah. Not to bad, holding up I guess", I lied, choking back the truth that I didn't know how to express. She walked over to me, gave me a gentle, tender hug. She smelt like Laura, they wore the same perfume, that soft rosy essence with a sharp edge that I’d grown to love, grown to rely on. I missed it. I craved it.
“You know”, Michelle started, “therapy is fine, its normal, it’s…everyone does it”. I could tell she knew what I was thinking.
“I’m good, really.” I tried to caress a smile to my face, my mouth wouldn’t even break a curve.
“Don’t lie to me,” she purred “I know when somethings up with you.” 
I just stood there, looking through her eyes into the void of despair I could tell she was also locking inside, as she portrayed her usual, outwardly confident self. I could tell it was consuming her to.

I picked up my coffee, sat back down on the couch and cried a little. A mans cry. The one that’s been bottled up for too long, but isn’t allowed to be seen. Laura. Out Laura. Dead. Everybody tells you grief is temporary, that it all ends, that there’s light at the end of the metaphorical tunnel. But through the grey-tinted veil of sorrow I was seeing the world through, I refused to believe that were true. And so, for the fourth time that day, I plugged myself in, and visited the farm which my Dad had grew up on. That peaceful farm, that simple farm. A farm in a world before Laura existed, well before her untimely demise. Some people scream, some people bottle it all up. But I found coping easiest when I turned to my MiniMind. Anything I wanted to be, anyone I wanted to be, always. It was easier that way. And so, I embraced the denial, and paid another visit to the animals.

Michelle stood leaning against the archway to the living room, watching her wreck of a husband drown himself in his virtual solitude. She knew he was getting worse. He was only in three times yesterday, once the day before. Now he was in for the fifth time today. And it was only two in the afternoon. She knew she should do something to help, she should not let him stay in, but maybe it was best for him? Maybe it would help? Her shoulders slumped and she let out an inaudible sigh. And she just stood there. Watching her husband drown in an oasis of opportunity, a world away. She just stood there for hours. And those hours eventually, turned to days.

She knew how dangerous that machine was, the MiniMind, it was an epidemic, really. The scientists said it was more addictive than heroin, and why wouldn’t it be? It was a portal to a world without pain, without suffering. And her husband had been in there for days now. Without eating, without sleeping. And she didn’t even have the stomach to intervene, because she knew, deep down, he was happy. And happiness was hard to come by. Much harder to maintain. She begged, silently, that he would come out by himself. That he would return to her and face the grief he was running from. To face his fear and beat it. 

But that never happened. He just stayed in. And slowly, Michelle watched as the man she loved turned into a shadow of his former self, rotting in the false existence he created. Until he was no longer a man at all. The machine got the better of him.

As it always does.
